item.title: Shortcuts
item.description: ctrl + alt + arrow up/down → change desktop ctrl + T → crate new tab ctrl + H → show hidden files ctrl + alt + F1/F2/... → open the tty console. Useful when desktop env. is blocked or for any other reason. One of the function key (typically F7) is used for the graphical session

item.title: Open Source Applications
item.description: This note provides a list of the main open source applications and softwares divided by categories and purposes. Server Web Server: Apache HTTPD (more complete), Nginx (lighter), Stack LAMP (Linux, Apache, MySQL, PHP - for web developers) Database: Postgre, MySQL, MariaDB Unix File Server: NFS Windows File Server: Samba Directory Server: OpenLDAP Desktop Office: LibreOffice, OpenOffice Browser: Firefox, Chromium Email Client: Thunderbird

item.title: Packages
item.description: tree → show the recursive directory structure as a tree view (starting from the current directory) htop → nice looking software to monitor processes in the terminal

item.title: Accessing Hardware Info
item.description: lsblk → access all the information about external drives (it menas ‘list block devices’). in Linux, all external storage devices are stored in /dev/sd*. Usualy, first letter (a,…) is the name of the disk, followed by a number if more that one partitions are present ip addr (or ifconfig, but it is deprecated) → lists all network cards lsusb → lists all USB peripherals (keyboard, mouse, serial ports,…)

item.title: Process Monitoring
item.description: A process is the instance of a program which is ebeing executed by the CPU. It contains the program code and its activity. Important parameters are: PID (Process ID), priority, occupied memory, used CPU percentage top → call the system manager to visualize all the processes top -M → use the best measurment unit in the column of the allocated memory of each process > P, > M → order processes for CPU percentage or memory percentage

item.title: System log
item.description: dmesg → display log of events happening with the peripherals of the OS (USB ports, network cards,…). dmesg -w → maintain occupied the bash session and display each new event in real time Other logs are contained in the /var/log/ directory.

item.title: Choosing a Distro
item.description: Debian Release Cycle There are mainly 4 versions of the _Debian _operating system: unstable (Sid) → every software update is immediatly released on this version, but it can be full of bugs testing (Buster) → after some time, if no bugs are fonund, software is released in the testing version of the OS. This can be a god compromise on desktop system to have software reasonably update and safe

item.title: VirtualBox
item.description: Create New Virtual Machine Click new and insert name for the OS. It should find the corresponding OS type. If not, select the right type and version; Assign RAM quantity (2GB for 8GB machines should be ok) Create new virtual HD > VDI > Dynamically allocated Select HD size (15GB should be ok) Select the machine and go to Settings General > Advanced tab > select Bidirectional in Shared Clipboard [can copy/paste between VM and base OS]
